title: Eight to join Sonora Wildcat Hall of Fame
text:
Eight to join Sonora Wildcat Hall of Fame Eight to join Sonora Wildcat Hall of Fame By The Union Democrat Sports Department October 07, 2015 01:00 am Jeff Juhl, class of 1969. File photo / Union Democrat. Eight athletes/coaches will be inducted into the Sonora High Wildcat Hall of Fame at 5 p.m. Saturday, Nov. 7, during a ceremony at the Elks Lodge. Dinner will be served at 6 p.m. and the awards ceremony will follow at 7. The cost is $40. For more information, call Rick Francis at 533-0364 or 206-1633. 
class of 1952 Rotelli was a three-sport athlete participating in football, track and tennis. In football he was selected to the all-conference team and was also the team captain. He was the Valley Oak League tennis champion in 1951 and 1952. Rotelli was awarded a football scholarship to Stanford University. He ended up playing two years at College of San Mateo playing guard and linebacker. He transferred to Idaho State University and played center and linebacker. For many years, Rotelli scouted for coach Bob Gibson and also coached the junior varsity football team for sixyears. Jeff Juhl class of 1969 Juhl participated in football, basketball and baseball. Juhl was brought up to the varsity football team his sophomore year to play quarterback. He was an all-league player his senior year and held the career passing yardage record upon his graduation. In baseball, Juhl made the all-league team as an infielder. His senior year he received the Fred Rowe award as the outstanding male athlete for the class of 1969. Juhl was also on the Sonora High football staff for 14 years coaching football at both the JV and varsity levels. Robert Cendro class of 1975 Cendro is being honored both as an athlete and as a coach. As an athlete, he participated in football, basketball and track. In football he was all -league in 1974 and played in the Lion’s All Star game. In 1974 he was a member of the VOL Championship track team where he excelled in the 400-meter run and relay teams. He went on to play football at Modesto Junior College where he was an all-league player for two years and was selected to their all decade team for the 70’s. Coming back to Sonora High, Cendro became a very successful coach. He guided the football team for 17 years and his teams earned the most wins in school history with three league titles, two section finals and made the playoffs 10 times. In track, which he coached for 11 years, his boys’ team won three section titles, twoleague titles with members of his team breaking seven school records. He coached softball for seven years where his teams won two VOL titles. He coached JV girls one season and coached for a total of 19 years at Sonora High. Roger Canepa class of 1981 Canepa is being honored as an athlete and as a coach. He was a three-sport athlete participating in football, wrestling and baseball. Canepa was an outstanding linebacker making the all-league team and being selected to the Lion’s All Star game. He wrestled for three years and played baseball four years. His enthusiasm for sports was recognized as he received the Jack Wivell award as the Most Inspirational Male Athlete for the class of 1984. Canepa also had a very successful colligate career in football at Butte Community College and Chico State University. He was chosen their MVP and most inspirational player. Canepa has had a fabulous coaching career. At Sonora High he coached football for 10 years. and also coached wrestling and track and field. Canepa went on to coach football at Calaveras and is currently coaching football at Central Catholic High School where his teams have won three consecutive state titles. He is the fourth coach in the history of the Sac-Joaquin Section to win over 200 games. Kelley Clifton Kull class of 1984 Clifton Kull was an outstanding athlete in two sports: volleyball and track. She was a three-year varsity letter winner in volleyball (also brought up for section playoffs her freshmen year). She was an outstanding setter being named the VOL Most Valuable Setter her senior year. During her sophomore and junior years she was named to the VOL honorable mention teams. In track she was one of the fastest girls on the team. She was on the VOL championship team where she was a member of the 4x100 relay team that set the school record three weeks in a row qualifying for the Section meet. Clifton Kull received the Mary York Most Inspirational Female Athlete for the class of 1984. Nicole Taylor Bitting class of 1988 Taylor Bitting was one of the finest three sport athletes to ever graduate from Sonora High School. Taylor Bitting was a fouryear varsity athlete in volleyball, basketball and softball. During her senior year, she was named the MVP in all three sports. In basketball she was named to the All-State team and the All-Northern California team. In 1986 Nicole lead her team to the first section basketball title in Sonora’s history. She was named the MVP of various tournaments. She was awarded a full scholarship to Loyola University. Jason Hart class of 1997 Many consider Hart one of the finest cross country and distance runners in track to ever wear the green and gold. In cross country, Hart was the VOL Champ in 1995 and 1996. He was the Sac-Joaquin Section Champ in 1996 and the State Champ in Division 3 the same year. In track, running the 3200 meters he was the VOL Champ in 1996 and 1997. Also in 1996 Jason ran and won the 3200 in a very prestigious meet in Europe. Tacy Riddle Duncan class of 1997 Riddle Duncan participated in basketball, cross country and softball during her high school career, but excelled in softball. She was a four-year varsity letter winner. She received VOL first team honors in 1995, 1996 and 1997. She was the league MVP in 1996, made the All-District team in 1996 and 1997. She was selected by the Modesto Bee as the Pitcher of the Year both in 1996 and 1997 along with being named player of the year in 1997. She was selected the Elks award as the Most Outstanding Female athlete for the class of 1997. She went on the play fouryears of collegiate softball making the state of Iowa’s Academic All-American team. She was also a two-time NAIA All-American. 
After college, she played professionally in Europe for the Czech Republic for eightmonths. Presently, Riddle Duncan is the women’s softball coach at Cal State San Bernandino. Follow UnionDemocrat.com
